DataElement.preferredName: Substance Abuse Illicit Substance Other Substance of Abuse Personal Medical History Specify
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the free text field to specify the other illicit substance of abuse used that may lead to social, occupational, psychological, or physical problems as part of a person's medical background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Substance Abuse Illicit Substance Other Substance of Abuse Personal Medical History
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to the use of an other (different than the one previously specified or mentioned) illegal drug (substances deemed as harmful and usually subject to legal restriction) substance of abuse (any substance, including any illegal, prescription, over-the-counter agent or any other compound, used for the purpose other than indicated or used in quantities other than directed), that may lead to social, occupational, psychological, or physical problems as part of a person's medical background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Maladaptive pattern of drug or alcohol use that may lead to social, occupational, psychological, or physical problems.

Concepts.definition: Maladaptive pattern of drug or alcohol use that may lead to social, occupational, psychological, or physical problems.

Property.preferredName: Illicit Substance Other Substance of Abuse Personal Medical History
Property.preferredDefinition: Something (as drugs or alcoholic beverages) deemed harmful and usually subject to legal restriction.:Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.:Any substance, including any illegal, prescription, over-the-counter agent or any other compound, used for the purpose other than indicated or used in quantities other than directed. Substances from various drug classes can be abused, such as opioids, amphetamines, analgesics, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, hallucinogens, steroids, tobacco products and alcoholic substances. A substance of abuse may act on the central nervous system (CNS) or can have an effect in other parts of the body and can lead to physical and/or physiological dependence.:an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: Something (as drugs or alcoholic beverages) deemed harmful and usually subject to legal restriction.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Any substance, including any illegal, prescription, over-the-counter agent or any other compound, used for the purpose other than indicated or used in quantities other than directed. Substances from various drug classes can be abused, such as opioids, amphetamines, analgesics, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, hallucinogens, steroids, tobacco products and alcoholic substances. A substance of abuse may act on the central nervous system (CNS) or can have an effect in other parts of the body and can lead to physical and/or physiological dependence.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredName: Chronic or Associated Diseases and Exposures
ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the text field to specify chronic or associated diseases and exposures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredName: Chronic or Associated Diseases and Exposures
ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Specify; be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: Be specific about something; define clearly.

ReferenceDocuments.name: PhenX Substances Protocol Lifetime Use
ReferenceDocuments.description: Any OTHER medicines, or drugs, or substances, for example, methadone, Elavil, steroids, Thorazine, or Haldol (specify)
